posts.cooked:
A new mechanisms library designed for FIRST Robotics Competition teams has been released. Built on top of existing libraries, this tool simplifies implementation of common mechanisms such as elevators, arms, and turrets. Key features include code-only configuration, built-in simulation and telemetry, and a command-based design integrating with WPILib components. 

The library offers a variety of ready-to-use mechanisms including elevators, single-jointed arms, and turrets. Each component comes with built-in simulation and telemetry support, eliminating the need for separate setups. Additionally, it provides advanced features like filmstrip analysis and minimal code requirements for functionality.

An example of how to use the library demonstrates its capabilities, showing how even complex systems can be implemented simply. The code includes a full arm subsystem using a TalonFXS motor with Configurable parameters like PID control and feedforward compensation. This example highlights the library's ability to abstract low-level complexities, allowing teams to focus on higher-level strategies.

This release marks a significant advancement in robotics education, enabling students to build simulations and real-world systems seamlessly. Future updates will continue to enhance compatibility and usability, with ongoing work on a web-based simulator and code generator. Stay tuned for more developments and join our community for updates.
Here is a demo video of it courtesy of @Konnor! image

posts.name: Joe Ross
posts.cooked:
nstrike:

We're excited to open beta access to a new mechanisms library (name TBD). I vote for Yet Another Mechanism LIbrary. Code-only configuration. No JSON files — everything is in Java. Configuration is also done in YAML.

posts.name: Owen Busler
posts.cooked: We use YAGSL with JSON config and YAML with YAML config. They are different because it's funny.
Maybe for april fools day we will add a yaml parser

posts.name: Chris Gerth
posts.cooked: Yamlib is pronounced like "Yamlib."
Knowing me, Y-A-M-L-I-B is more likely

posts.name: Mr. Siefen | 453
posts.cooked:
Dear diary,  
After months of preparation, lots of long sleepless nights—I’ve finally achieved the dream. YAGSL is a recognized CD abbreviation! I can now move on to YAGAL (Yet Another Generic Arm Library) for simplifying 6DOF pose estimation and control.  

/J Aabove  
Seriously congrats!  

It only took 6 months from my joke! This is much better than my original idea—so seriously awesome work! Can’t wait to try this out.

posts.name: Eli Barnett
posts.cooked: One of the cooler possibilities for 2026: seeding a mechanism in the generator with a ReCalc link, and getting code with approximate control gains already templated in!

user_custom_fields.user_field_4: Robot apartments! invisible suburbs! skeleton treasuries!

posts.cooked: Once your PR is accepted for "recalc", I will modify the URL to generate the mechanism generator, which currently does not fully support it. However, I will not alter it in such a way that the forms remain a 1:1 duplicate. If teams desire more granular control, they can modify the recalc page accordingly.

posts.name: Totally out of touch
posts.cooked: What is your plan to account for different latency, frequency, backlash, and noise across implementations and product ecosystems?

posts.name: Eli Barnett
posts.cooked: On the Recalc side, for anything that we can’t infer from the page config you have to affirmatively enter a nonzero value into a box with a big red border and a warning label telling you not to just make it up. There’s nothing we can do about the fundamental issue of “if you specify your mechanism wrong then the gains will be wrong.” But, the code generator should be able to correctly enter the gains in the right units for you, at least.

user_custom_fields.user_field_4: Robot apartments! invisible suburbs! skeleton treasuries!

posts.cooked: The code generator should be able to correctly enter the gains in the right units. It will do so even though they may appear dimensionless, which doesn't solve the problem of units but represents progress in the right direction.

This might not be very relevant to the topic but RIP to our team’s offseason project. We have intended to develop a one-size-fits-all mechanism system that includes simulation logging and feedforward calculations. Although similar to what you are doing we planned to utilize Isaac Sim and support for multiple mechanisms. 

Our URL map shows the following file:微信图片_20250625235046 with dimensions 1920×1382 and size 286 KB. 

The good news is that we haven’t invested too much effort yet so we can gradually modify the framework and incorporate features like multi-mechanism implementation. 

This is indeed an impressive project and I truly appreciate everyone’s hard work in creating this fantastic library.

posts.name: Ethan Grieshop
posts.cooked: This is crazy. We might be a couple years out from lower-level FRC software being 100% plug and play. Imagine a world where every team can start from a baseline and focus on higher level integration and automation.

Next season you should be able to plug everything into the code gen and tune your mechanism theoretically assuming “normal” weight distribution. Then you can take those values and plug them into the mechanism library and have an FRC sim and replay capability with minimal changes.

posts.name: Curt Rozeboom
posts.cooked: IDK about plug-n-play, but hearing a team say, "We designed our robot in code before we built it", would certainly be interesting.
Hey, that's my plan for this season with my three teams!
Looking at this, it’s different enough from what I made and envisioned—if you’d like me to provide in-depth feedback on your design, even without building it, let me know!

posts.name: Eli Barnett
posts.cooked: We might be a couple years out from lower-level FRC software being 100% plug and play. Per the above discussion on units and GIGO, I don’t think “100% plug and play” is a thing that can ever really be achieved. But we can definitely get to a place where there is never any need to reverse-engineer someone else’s starter template.

user_custom_fields.user_field_4: Robot apartments! invisible suburbs! skeleton treasuries!
